Dear Mr. Clark:
First I want you to know how pleased I am that the NAEB finally
appointed someone to this most important position. 1 Have"'long been
H isappointed~that they had not done more in~~this area before.
I am enclosing a number of materials on programs WBFO has pro¬
duced and is planning in this area. Our record goes back to 1965 when we
did a series entitled, TO BE NEGRO, to let the white community know what
it feels like to be a Negro in our society. One of our black students
did an excellent documentary on Resurrection City; we sent this to
NER network but I don*t believe they distributed it and it is, of course*
no longer current. We did a series called, NATION WITHIN A NATION, on
the Iroquois Confederation which several stations around the country have
used and it is still available and timely. You will see from one of the
enclosed program guides that we ran the guide as advertising in Buffalo*s
largest Negro weekly and sent this to our predominantly ’white subscribers
as another medium of communicating black thought and culture.
We had offered the enclosed proposal to the Ford Foundation for
funding a studio in the black ghetto to be staffed by black personnel.
We have good black support for this idea but unfortunately we donlt have
the funds. I do plan, however, to go ahead with a more limited project of
this nature using some existing university facilities and staffing it with
black students who work at WBFO. You can see from some of the enclosed
material a description of a pilot project we had in this regard last summer.
I don*t see this as a "summertime only" activity, and all our efforts are
not aimed at "cooling it" for the summer but to provide ongoing communication
from this all too separate and unknown part of society.
My personal feeling is that the network being contemplated by the Ford
Foundation will have little value if local stations are not also doing even
